reviewText: I kind of all sorts of love Billy Wilder!  I mean it; I've seen a number of his films and almost always he really excites me.  In fact, I can only think of one of his films (off the top of my head) that really didn't work for me (`Stalag 17').  I have been chomping at the bit to finally see `A Foreign Affair' since a few of my cinephile friends adore it, and so last night I did myself a big favor and settled in to watch it.Please be forewarned, this is a film you may need to digest before truly appreciating it.`A Foreign Affair' is a political satire of sorts that deals with a love triangle overseas involving an Army Captain, a former Nazi conspirator and a Congresswoman.  Phoebe Frost is a prickly pear, a cold and seemingly critical Congresswoman who makes a routine trip to occupied Berlin to make a morality check on the men in arms.  When she gets there she is blown away by the brazen bad behavior displayed by the men serving her country.  There is one beacon of light though, a Captain John Pringle.  He appears to be a morally acceptable man, despite his dark secret.  He is currently shacking up with a café singer named Erika Von Schluetow who is a former Nazi.Chaos ensues when Phoebe falls for John while investigating Erika.I will be honest; when the film started I was afraid I wasn't going to like it much.  Sometimes these older comedies have trouble translating to a modern crowd.  That isn't to knock them in any way, it's just that unless you were present at the time and circumstances with which the film was shot you may not understand the humor in some of the jokes.  So, I wasn't laughing and it bothered me.  As the film progressed though, the human elements of the film and the remarkable performances (especially by the female leads) made for a truly engrossing and rewarding experience.  Jean Arthur is simply amazing here.  I love her brand of comedy.  She really understands how to layer a character.  Marlene Dietrich is the films dramatic center, and she handles it flawlessly.  I'm not too keen on her singing voice, but she sold the performance aspect of her character brilliantly.She knows how to smolder.In the end I'm handing this film an A.  I was teetering back and forth between a B+ and an A- and I settled on an A after realizing that my ONLY reservation was the first ten minutes or so it took me to get settled into the films themes.  Once I understood the direction the film was going and got grounded on the films sense of humor it became an engrossing and highly entertaining satire that I will certainly revisit!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Marlene Dietrich, Jean Arthur and John Lund star in A FOREIGN AFFAIR, a humorous romantic drama centered around post-war Berlin.Erika Von Shluetow (Marlene Dietrich) is an ex-Nazi now reduced to doing cabaret in a blackmarket nightclub.  She is being courted by an American soldier, Captain Pringle (John Lund).On her way to Berlin is Phoebe Frost (Jean Arthur), an icy woman from America, who is going to record her visit and report back to the government.  Erika is meant to be doing time in a labour camp for her Nazi dealings, but Pringle always manages to get her through.Phoebe finds out about her and decides to track her down, and Pringle decides the only way he can save her life is to lead on Phoebe and bribe her into letting Erika go.Billy Wilder's film is a joyous delight, with Dietrich and Arthur in top form.  Dietrich performs the Frederick Hollander songs 'Black Market', 'Illusions', and 'Ruins Of Berlin'.In reality Dietrich was horrified at the thought of playing a Nazi femme fatale, as she was very strongly against Hitler and what he was doing to her homeland.  During the war she entertained the Allied troops.

reviewText: Billy Wilder was such a genius in film-making,it's astounding. What really set him apart, I think, was his knack for knowing who to cast in what role. What really gives this film its kick, is Marlene Dietrich in a role that proved once and for all that yes, she can act!Set in Berlin right after the end of World War Two, and at the beginning of the American occupation of their sector of Berlin,the film is really a dialogue on the human trait of survival through the worst. The main charactors are bent on surviving their individual circumstances, as each interacts with the others in the story.Dietrich portrays a former Nazi lounge singer, keeping an American officer sugar-daddy so she can stay alive and well in Berlin, John Lund plays her American officer on a leash, and Jean Arthur is the upright(and uptight) US congresswoman from Iowa who throws a wrench into everybodys life by arriving to check on troop morale.This film has many truly wicked one-liners, and puts one to mind of Dietrich's days with Von Sternberg, what with all the shadows and over-head lights. Certainly, Dietrich definately benefited from this, she never looked at all her 47 years. Jean Arthur, I've heard, wasn't pleased with the pains Dietrich took with the lighting, but mainly she wasn't too thrilled with her part. She needn't have worried. She portrays the straight-laced congresswoman perfectly, the right foil to Dietrich's sultry singer. Each actor is just right in their role, and one also wonders why John Lund sort of disappeared after this, he was very good in this film.The cast and script are just perfect, and the lighting and photography are top-notch. This film was a sucess, but due to its subject matter and time frame(at a time when most americans still thought of Germany as the enemy), it wasn't a huge hit. However, it did rejuvenate Dietrich's career yet again, for perhaps the hundredth time. Well worth having in your collection!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This underrated Wilder comedy is more pleasurable than some of his more acclaimed, 'serious' films.  it badly needs the Preston Sturges touch - to excise those longueurs for a start - but it has an agreeable sourness that poisons any move towards fairy-tale resolution.  When the most sympathetic character in this tale of the US Army and senators is an opportunistic Nazi turned 'nightclub singer', you get where Wilder's coming from.His vision of American military imperialism is presciently negative, astonishingly so in 1948, as is the sexual frankess, the shifting sado-masochism of Lund's relationship with Dietrich (linked to Nazism); the bawdy innuendo of that with Jean Arthur.  The film also works as a tribute to Marlene Dietrich, a creation of light and mirrors who,unlike 'earthier' stars like Arthur, will never be caught.

reviewText: The movie shows what Berlin looked like shortly after the war in a light hearted way of course.  But it was a charming love story.
summary: One of the few movies made in Berlin after the war.

reviewText: "A Foreign Affair" (1948) is a Billy Wilder film starring Jean Arthur, Marlene Dietrich, and John Lund that takes place in post WW 2 Berlin.The film was written and directed by the great Billy Wilder whose screenwriting credits include Oscar nominated "Ninotchka" (1939), "Double Indemnity" (1944),  "Stalag 17" (1953), "Witness for the Prosecution" (1957), and "Some Like it Hot" (1959). Charles Brackett was his writing partner on this film as well as 12 others including "Midnight" (1939), "Ninotchka" (1939), "Hold Back the Dawn" (1941), "The Lost Weekend" (1945) and "Sunset Blvd" (1950).When it comes to comedies, Wilder has a hit ("Some Like it Hot", Stalag 17", "The Apartment", "Irma la Douce") and miss ("Kiss Me Stupid", "Buddy Buddy", "Sabrina", "One Two Three", "Love in the Afternoon") track record, and the comedy elements in this film clearly fall into the "miss" category. For the first 30 minutes you'll barely break a snicker.Jean Arthur (1900-91) stars as an Iowa Congresswoman investigating troop morale in post war Berlin. Arthur is best known for her films with Frank Capra ("Mr. Deeds Goes to Town", "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington"). She was a marvelous comedienne known for her "screwball" comedies like "You Can't Take it With You" (1938), but she had a wide range of skills and made "Only Angels Have Wings" (1939), and "The Devil and Miss Jones" (1941). She was nominated for an Oscar for "The More the Merrier" (1943).FWIW - Arthur retired in 1944 and was lured back to the screen by Wilder, which is a good thing, because her next and final film was the classic "Shane" (1953).Marlene Dietrich (1901-92) plays a nightclub entertainer (3 musical numbers by Frederick Hollander) and former girlfriend of a highly placed Nazi who is being "kept" by an Army Captain (Lund). Dietrich appeared in more than a dozen films, some as early as 1919, before she had her "breakthrough" in "The Blue Angel" (1929). She was a major star in the 30s ("Morocco", "Shanghai Express", "Destry Rides Again") and was nominated for an Oscar ("Morocco" in 1930) and a Golden Globe ("Witness for the Prosecution" in 1957 - my personal Dietrich favorite).  Here in 1947 she was trying to get her career moving again after a series of poor box office showings ("Golden Earrings", "Pittsburgh", "The Spoliers").BTW - Dietrich was a staunch anti-Nazi. As a German who became a US citizen, she worked tirelessly entertaining troops and was vilified by the Nazis and her remaining family in Germany was threatened with retaliation. So it was ironic that she plays a Nazi sympathizer.Handsome John Lund (1911-92) plays the Army officer romancing Dietrich and later Arthur, both of whom were considerably older than he. He made two dozen films, mostly comedies, beginning in 1946 ("To Each His Own") and including "My Friend Irma" (1949), "High Society" (1956), and "If a Man Answers" (1962).Gruff Millard Mitchell (1903-53) plays Lund's superior officer. Mitchell won the Golden Globe in 1952 for "My Six Convicts". He made only 37 films but was always memorable. I liked him best in "Twelve O'clock High" (1949) as Gregory Peck's commanding officer."Parts" of this movie were filmed in post war Berlin and there are some marvelous pictures of the bombed out city. Wilder had been a resident of Berlin, and when the war ended, he flew to the city and took some of the footage that was later used in this film.  Mostly the city footage is used as a backdrop and the foreground consists of studio shots. Nonetheless this is one of the best records of what post war Berlin looked like (see also "Berlin Express").Charles Lang is the cinematographer. Lang was nominated more times for an Oscar than any other Director of Photography (18 times), but won only once - "A Farewell to Arms" (1934). The nearly 150 films he photographed differed in content and style, as Lang was an eclectic. He lensed such diverse films as "Wait Until Dark" (1967), "How the West was Won" (1962), "Some Like it Hot" (1959), "The Big Heat" (1953), "The Ghost and Mrs. Muir" (1947), and "The Lives of a Bengal Lancer" (1935).Production was problematic with Wilder being perceived by Arthur as favoring Dietrich, who was a fellow Berliner.  Billy Wilder said "I have one dame who's afraid to look at herself in a mirror and another who won't stop looking!"In 1948, Bogart and Huston teamed up to make the #4 ("Treasure of the Sierra Madre") and #12 ("Key Largo") top grossing film of the year and went on to win two Oscars (Director, Supporting Actor). Other top 10 grossing films were "The Red Shoes", "The Three Musketeers", "Red River", "Easter Parade", "Johnny Belinda", "The Snake Pit" and "Joan of Arc".Bosley Crowther of the NY Times called the film "dandy entertainment which has some shrewd and realistic things to say" by "making light of regulations and the gravity of officialdom in a smoothly sophisticated and slyly sardonic way." He praised Lund ("disarmingly shameless"), Arthur ("beautifully droll") and Dietrich ("restless femininity") as well as the screen writers ("wit, worldliness and charm").The film was nominated for an Oscar for Best Cinematography and Best Screenplay, but didn't win.One of the problems with this film is the tone. Considered a "romantic comedy", the film's focus is on corruption, prostitution, and deceit, and while these can be handled in a funny way, they are inserted in the film between flimsy attempts at comedy. So, "yes" there are a few laughs here and "yes" it's always great to see Marlene Dietrich perform,. and "yes" the film does have some important things to say about post war politics and indeed about politics itself. But the stew is lumpy and the ingredients don't really mix that well.Bottom line - a failed effort at a black comedy, but some good scenes and great photography of post war Berlin.

reviewText: I have the movie in VHS and consider it a must-have for the Dietrich collector.  The VHS had been chopped at the ends, as usual, to accommodate the TV screen.  The VHS did have some rather amusing contemporary promotional material at the beginning.  The DVD, just bought, is also chopped at the ends, seemingly even more.  The absence of the outer 40 % or so of the image is a callous affront.  No special features of any kind, no scene selection, no contemporary promo material.  Just jam it in the slot and click on play.  The plus is great picture quality - what there is of it.
summary: Cheap repro ripoff.  Minuses outweigh the pluses.

summary: Marlene's a treat for the eyes in this one...
Title: N/A

reviewText: Billy Wilder and Charles Brackett adapted this jewel from a post war novel and the dialogue crackels with wit and intelligence from the first frame on. It is a wonderfully cynical take on The Marshall Plan and how three lives intersect in the bombed out ruins of Berlin, circa 1947. Dietrich is delicious as a caberet singers trying to survive after being a plaything of a Gestapo Colonel. In her late forties, Dietrich lights up the screen she appears to be ageless. Jean Arthur is playing a corn fed, button downed Congress woman from Iowa and these two ladies vye for the  affections of an American Captain played by John Lund (who's very appealing in this role). Lots of social commentary woven into the story and the footage of the ruins of Berlin is staggering. This is a fine Wilder film that doesn't always make it on his list of achievments but it is worth the time and money to hear that great Wilder and Brackett badinage.

reviewText: ....... IT SEEMS THAT THE MOVIE WAS SOMEHOW HIDDEN TO A MODERN AUDIENCE.....I HAD HEARD THAT IT WAS A DIFFICULT DIETRICH FILM TO SEE.  JEAN ARTHUR.  NEARLY HER LAST FILM.  ONLY "SHANE".  I DO NOT KNOW WHAT ALL THESE IDEA'S MEAN.  THEY HAD FILMED ARTHUR IN A TERRIBLE WAY?  FAVORED DIETRICH? ...  I'M NOT SURE.WELL ARTHUR AND DIETRICH WERE OF THE SAME AGE...... I HAVE CUT MY TEETH ON THIS FILM, AND, WELL YOU CAN'T HAVE ONE WITHOUT THE OTHER.  I AM NOT SURE HOW ARTHUR COULD HAVE BEEN MADE BETTER,,,,OR DIETRICH MADE TO BE AN IOWA WAY BITCH.IT SEEMS CORRECT TO THINK THAT IT WAS THE END OF THE WAR,,, AND WHAT A WAY TO MAKE A PICTURE.  DIETRICH EXPLAINING HOW THEY GOT THROUGH THE WAR,,,,, WAS NOT SO DIFFEREN'T AS TO THE WAY,,, EVERYONE GOT THROUGH THE WAR.  THAT WILDER MADE IT SEEM FUN? OH WELL, WATCH THE FILM.  THE FILM IS GETTING SO DIFFICULT TO WATCH,,,,, TO BE SEEN.  QUICK LIKE A BUNNY'  GET IT WHILE YOU CAN.  YOU WILL HAVE A SMILE ON YOUR FACE,,,,,,, AND MUCH TO THINK ABOUT....  JOY!!

reviewText: Funny, funny, funny! A delight to watch, and the nightclub singing of Marlene Dietrich is great. The filming on location is realistic and gives you the backdrop of the greatest confilct and destruction that the Nazi regieme caused. Whew! Who knew Nazi hunting would be so funny, but this is Billy Wilder directing, he was a creative genius at this mad cap genere. Check out One, Two, Three!
summary: Post WW II situation comedy in bombed out Berlin

reviewText: An Iowa congresswoman (Jean Arthur) is sent to the ruins of Berlin after the war to check on the moral of U.S. troupes.  What she finds is a bunch of soldiers having too much fun with the German women, including an Army  Captain, (John Lund) who is having too much fun with Marlene Dietrich, a  local caberet entertainer and Nazi.  Arthur tries to expose Dietrich's Nazi  past, while at the same time Lund is trying to protect her.  And of course,  Arthur falls in love with Lund in the process.  The comedy is directed by  the great Billy Wilder, who flew a film crew to Berlin to shoot scenes of  the bombed-out city, making it look like the entire film was shot on  location.  Dietrich was given 3 songs to perform in the film,  "Illusions", "Black Market", and "Ruins of  Berlin". She had returned to the role that made her famous almost 20  years earlier.  At first, Dietrich didn't want to do the film because of  her characters association with the Nazi party.  She eventually took the  part after Billy Wilder convinced her how fabulous a role it was.  "Foreign Affair" was a major success for Dietrich, putting her  back at the top of the list of Hollywoods most glamours leading ladies.  During filming, legendary costumer Edith Head was quoted as saying  "...you don't design clothes 'for' Dietrich, you design them 'with'  her."  This film is a must see for all Dietrich fans.  It is one of  the last films of Dietrich to be made available on video, and like they  say, they save the best for last!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Searching out post WWII films set in Berlin reveals a rich dramatic landscape, from Berlin Express to The Big Lift. Billy Wilder'sA Foreign Affair is not quite as black as Ace In the Hole, but the roadmap is certainly there. This is a witty and biting black comedythat looks frankly at the post-war morality of a barely recovering Berlin. Wilder also sends up the American Politics and neatlycontrasts European and New World social mores. It's so elegantly written and structured, however, you might just miss all thaton the first pass. That's good, because A Foreign Affair is worth many, many viewings.
summary: Lesser Known Wilder Is Choice, Bitter and Very Funny
Title: N/A

reviewText: A Foreign Affair is a film about post-WWII Germany filled with demolished buildings, the American army, and sex. Some American Congressmen (and women) go to check on the status of the moral and the troops only to find that things are far different than they are perceived to be back home.Jean Arthur plays a frumpy Congresswoman out to find corruption and get rid of it. Arthur is funny and appropriately prudish in her role. She is an average beauty with a knack for being nervous and likable, a girl-next-door type. Her character falls in love with an army officer played by John Lund who seduces her in order to hide the fact that his lover is a former Nazi.John Lund is an adept actor who gets to show off his skills by being humorous, serious, and romantic all in the same film.Marlene Dietrich plays the Nazi lover, a departure from her true wartime image. She is wry, intelligent, and seductive in her role, a true asset to the film.There are three songs in this film as there often are in Dietrich films. The first is "Black Market," a low key nightclub song which is mostly spoken. It is a complex song lyrically, but the melody is mellow and slow. The second song is "Illusion," an absolutely gorgeous tune sang surprisingly well by Dietrich. This is the song that will stick in your head after the film is over. The last song is called "The Ruins of Berlin," a fun song sung in Dietrich's typical vibrating voice.This film is filled with drama and comedy, making it appealing for a wide audience. The ending is appropriate and the story is never boring.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Hard to believe this film is barely acknowledged today,except in maybe a cultish way. If Carroll Reeds' THE THIRD MAN was the great post-war Vienna must-see, Billy Wilder's A FOREIGN AFFAIR must be the great post-war Berlin must-see. This one starts out with some of the best aerial footage of bombed-out Berlin ever seen. The ruins seem to go on for miles. Certain burnt-out US soldiers main concerns are making a killing on the black market, and making a hit with the local Frauleins. Mr. Lund's character says it best, that  he,like many of his peers, is sick of the battles, politics,phony causes, and just  wants to live, if that's possible. The civilians go from one moment to the next in earnest persuit of mere survival. The naive US Congresswoman(Arthur) wants to "reform" these military slackers,but she slowly realizes her cause is pretty pointless. Then we have the sultry cabaret singer (Dietrich) living in a bombed out ruin,who may have some answers to nasty questions about war criminals. Some great scenes are here,including Mr. Lund doing the old tablecloth trick (ie. pulling off a tablecloth so the silverware stays in place.) Great bar/carbaret scenes with Marlene making an attempt to keep the drunken soldiers under control. And a lot more...Like THE THIRD MAN, this one reeks with world weary atmosphere and cynicism, the latter a staple in any Wilder movie. Don't miss this one!!
summary: An almost unknown classic by a great director!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: AS a teenager I saw this wonderful movie and I do mean wonderful... movies like this just aren't made anymore.  The opening scene is the real Berlin after world war II had ended.  It's just rubble, nothing looks as if it survived thewar, it is shown as Jean Arthur a congresswoman has come to Berlin to investigate all the American mens affairs With German women giving birth to their babies...  Well the head Honcho played by John Lund is having is own affair with Marlene Dietrich.  She trading sex for cigarettes, candies and other scarce commodities in war ravaged Berlin.  Deitrich has never look better in her career.  Her voice in the songs specifically written for her by Frederick Hollander fits her to a Tee !!  Jean Arthur as the rattled congresswoman who smitten with John Lund and ends up in the triangle is just such fun... I can't imagine why this has not been  re-released and John Lund is as probably the high point in his career.
